Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in DRMS: Who's at stake? Nonhuman agency concepts and cultural resource conflict among Indigenous and Western actors in Panama

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research engages a fundamental question for cognitive science and decision making: what is at stake in cultural resource conflict over human-environment interactions? One of the most fundamental concepts under debate involves what-or-who is at stake in environmental dilemmas. Understanding people's environmental behavior requires understanding how they relate to other life forms as intentional agents worthy of moral consideration. This interdisciplinary research investigates how concepts of nonhuman agency interrelate with environmental cognition and decision making across two communities living in a shared ecosystem: Indigenous Ng√∂be and mainstream (Ladino, Euro-American) actors in Bocas del Toro, Panama (also including selected comparisons to standard U.S. samples). Studies employ cognitive and psychological methods to target key predictions concerning cultural variation in nonhuman agency concepts, and associated reasoning about moral circles and ecological causation. It is predicted that cultural differences in cognition will lead individuals to approach environmental decision making in very different ways: either as an ecological question that positions humans as users and protectors of the environment, or as a social question that positions both humans and nonhumans as intentional stakeholders in shared community.

This dissertation research will advance cognitive theory by offering a novel analysis of the conceptual frameworks involved in reasoning about nature across cultures, providing insight into the moral and causal dimensions of ecological thought. A distinct advantage of this work is its focus on under-represented perspectives of indigenous communities, contributing to the diversity of social science study populations and offering a unique vantage point on environmental questions. By documenting how cultural concepts and values impact perceptions of environmental tradeoffs, this research sheds light on cultural resource conflict (and cooperation) between indigenous and mainstream groups. More broadly, the results will deepen knowledge about the cultural and cognitive factors underlying environmental decision making, speaking to core issues in the decision science of human-environment interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research engages a fundamental question for the environment and society: What is at stake in cultural resource conflict over human-environment interactions? One of the most fundamental concepts under debate involves what—or who—is at stake in environmental dilemmas. Understanding people’s environmental behavior requires understanding how they relate to other life forms as active agents and moral subjects. Our research investigates how concepts of nonhuman agency interrelate with environmental cognition and decision-making among Indigenous Ngöbe and mainstream (Ladino, European-American) individuals in Bocas del Toro, Panama, with selected comparisons to U.S. college students. Our studies employed cognitive-psychological methods to target key questions concerning cultural variation in nonhuman agency concepts and associated ecological and moral reasoning.

Our research contributes to the understanding of cultural and ecological cognition in four important ways. First, we produced empirical cognitive evidence to clearly differentiate Western concepts of mind as human-centered phenomenon (referred to as folkpsychology) from Ngöbe concepts of communication as an ecological phenomenon (what we refer to as folkcommunication). Results from several studies and converging methods indicated that Ngöbe individuals have access to an ecocentric conceptual framework where agency is inferred on the basis of interactions and relationships. This framework allows Ngöbe individuals to recognize a wide range of non-animal actors as agents—including plants, the sun, and ocean—on the basis of their capacity to interact with elements of the environment. As a consequence of these distinct folktheories, we found that various conceptual dimensions of agency are parsed differently across cultures, including cognition, experience, and life. The Ngöbe theory of folkcommunication represents an alternative to what has often been assumed to be a universal conceptual framework of folkpsychology.

Second, drawing this new theoretical distinction allowed us to investigate whether the Ngöbe framework provides empirically productive grounds for inferring how nonhuman agents actually behave in nature. To test this, we assessed participants’ intuitive expectations for plant behavior in novel reasoning scenarios modeled on findings from botanical science. Ngöbe adults were more likely than US college students to predict that plants can communicate and engage in kin altruism, aligning with scientific findings. These results provide evidence that US and Ngöbe concepts of nonhuman agency are not just abstract theories: instead, they guide distinct modes of reasoning about real-world instances of natural agency.

Third, we investigated whether taking distinct stances on nonhuman agency would lead individuals to engage in contrasting modes of environmental decision-making. In this study, we explored whether Ngöbe and US ideas about nonhuman agents lead to distinct styles of environmental moral reasoning. Results showed that when considering hypothetical actions that would harm the environment for human utility (e.g., killing plants for medicine), both Ngöbe and US adults were concerned about environmental sustainability. However, Ngöbe adults were uniquely concerned to avoid causing suffering to plants, and this led them to be more conservative in their judgments about causing environmental harm. These results are informing research investigating the hypothesis that US frameworks treat environmental decision-making as an ecological question that positions humans as users and protectors of the environment, whereas Indigenous Ngöbe frameworks treat is as a social question that positions both humans and nonhumans as intentional stakeholders in shared community.

Fourth, this research program advances conceptions of culture and cognition by analyzing patterns of variability both within and across groups. In each study, we used cultural consensus modeling to identify whether multiple models of agency were present among Ngöbe and US community members. These findings demonstrated the plurality of conceptual orientations within a culture, especially the Ngöbe community. They also highlighted individual characteristics associated with membership in each consensus model, showing how an individual’s engagement with cultural lifeways (e.g., labor, university) can be associated with cultural ways of thinking.

In summary, our research findings enrich cognitive science and environmental psychology by offering a novel analysis of the conceptual frameworks involved in reasoning about nature across cultures, providing insight into the moral and causal dimensions of ecological thought. By documenting how cultural concepts and values impact perceptions of environmental tradeoffs, this research sheds light on cultural resource conflict (and cooperation) between Indigenous and mainstream groups. More broadly, results serve to deepen knowledge about the cultural and cognitive factors underlying environmental decision-making, speaking to core issues in the decision science of human-environment interactions.

A distinct advantage of our work is its focus on under-represented perspectives of Indigenous communities, contributing to the diversity of social science study populations and offering a unique vantage point on environmental questions. A complementary aim was to support Ngöbe community development objectives. Documenting environmental cognition contributes to the community-led Ngöbe Language and Cultural Education Program, which aims to preserve and maintain cultural knowledge for the next generation.

We wish to acknowledge the members of the Ngöbe community who have generously contributed their time, support, and expertise for all phases of this project.
